definition: The location where accused witches were kept when awaiting their trial and before executions. This could be the local Tolbooth, church or castle.
The recorded residences for accused witches at the time of their trial.
Major landowners, high status, inherited titles and lands. People from this category did not work their land or perform a craft, they lived off rents and income from property.

People in this category were wealthy, they often had access to land and/or property but no titles. They can be distinguished from Lairds/Barons and Nobility/Chief because they usually had to work for their living. They were more successful than the middling category either because they were very successful at their work or were employed in more lucrative professions. They include wealthy burgesses, important merchants, top level craftsmen (silversmiths, surgeons, etc.), tacksmen (leaseholders), advocates/lawyers. Some people in this category had as much or more wealth as the Lairds/Barons or Nobility/Chiefs, but they earned it and did not generally have titles.

High status landowners with inherited titles and lands, but not the top rung of land holding society. These people were usually referred to as the laird of somewhere. People in this category did not work their land or perform a craft. They lived off rents or other kinds of income.

This category was assigned to people who had a secure access tenancy of land and/or were secure craftsmen. The category includes tenant farmers (variously described, e.g. 'portioner'), baillies/factors, burgesses, lesser craftsmen (bakers, skinners, weavers, cordiners, fleshers, etc.), and ministers. These were people who had to work the land or at a craft for their living but were doing OK.

Quite poor, but people assigned this category had some access to land and at least some kind of employment. They were subtenants, semi-skilled artisans, colliers, gardeners, fishermen, workmen or sailors.

People in this category had some, limited access to land/employment to provide a meagre living. They include cottars (cottagers), servants in small households, grassmen, shepherds, and other types of odd jobs.
People without any access to any land or steady work, often described as vagrants or vagabonds.
Worked with iron and steel to create tools, nails, furniture, pots, knives, and hinges.
A female brewer.
Someone that works with mining coal.
Someone who delivered messages, packages, and letters between people.
A person who would make wicker baskets in which fish would be put inside.
Also known as cunning men and women, these were people who used folk healing methods and folk medicine in order to help heal sick people and animals.
Someone who worked on the land and kept livestock to produced food.
A person who caught fish for a living.
Someone who used folk healing methods in order to help people who were ill and in pain. Similar to Cunning Folk.
Someone who raises chickens and other poultry. In folklore they are often associated with the role of a healer.
A packman or carrier, using packhorse.
Someone who made malt, used to make beer and some foods.
A miller, of especially oatmeal, who buys grain in bulk to retail after grinding.
Someone involved in trade, they sold and bought goods. Higher social level of occupation.
Someone who would use metals to create useful objects. Similar to a Blacksmith.
A person who would help women deliver babies. Often involved in folk healing and medicine.
A person who operates a mill to ground grain in order to make foodstuffs such as flour.
Work where a worker is paid to carry out a certain work for a set price.
A person in charge of a school and its pupils.
A person in the employment of a someone, usually of higher social classification, who would carry out domestic activities for them.
A person who slates roofs for a living
A keeper of a stable where people would put their horses.
Someone who would make clothes for a living, such as trousers, jackets, and coats for individuals.
A person who does not have a set job or home, makes living by begging.
Someone who weaved and cared for fabric for a living.
Consulting a witch or magical healer. The suspect was charged with consulting or using a witch; not necessarily with being a witch.
The case contained demonic elements such as meetings with the Devil and other demonological topics.
The witch was accused of causing someone (a victim) to be possessed by the Devil. This usually involves an accusation of causing a particular type of ‘bewitchment’ involving convulsions and visions.
The case mentioned fairies/elves and fairy/elf motifs
The suspect was named as a witch by another accused witch during their interrogation.
The suspect was accused of causing magical harm following quarrels among neighbours.
The record lacks sufficient details to characterize the case.
A non-natural being appeared in the form of a demon, distinct from the Devil.
The case involved a dynastic or political struggle.
The case involved an attempt to obtain the property of the witchcraft suspect.
The witchcraft suspect was denied charity by a social superior, who then accused them of witchcraft.
The suspect used herbs, ointments, and objects believed to have healing properties on the sick or injured, aligned with folk healing practices.
The witchcraft accusation was linked to treason, such as accusations of witches plotting to kill the king or conspiring against the state.
Non-malicious magic used for healing, finding lost items, divination, or love spells, not intended to harm.
The suspect practiced midwifery, assisting women during childbirth.
The suspect was accused of engaging in religious practices outside officially sanctioned Protestant or Catholic orthodoxy.
The accused used religious practices considered unorthodox according to popular folk beliefs.
An agreement made with the Devil, often involving the exchange of one's soul or services for supernatural powers or favors.
Renunciation of Christian baptism, seen as an act of apostasy and a pact with the Devil.
Giving oneself over completely to the Devil, involving surrender of both body and soul.
The person who pays the caution or bail is under bond of caution, potentially involving the accusation of making a pact with the Devil.
A mark received from the Devil as a sign of pact, often described as insensible to feeling.
Touching the head and foot with opposite hands, symbolizing dedication or allegiance to the Devil.
Worship of the Devil in a manner that perverts or inverts Christian symbolism.
A new name given to a witch by the Devil, indicating a rejection of Christian baptism and a renaming by the Devil.
A general, non-specific pact made with the Devil, involving an agreement with supernatural entities.
Indicates that the accused had agreed to be the Devil’s servant, fulfilling tasks or services for the Devil.
Indicated that the accused had sexual relations with the Devil, often considered a grave act of spiritual and moral corruption.
The accused used power of the pact but did not describe any specific features, implying an implicit agreement or understanding with the Devil.
The accused confessed that the Devil promised to provide everything for them and that they ‘should never want’, indicating complete dependence on the Devil's provisions.
A cereal crop, usually oats, bere (a variety of barley), or wheat, which could be damaged or destroyed, often attributed to witchcraft.
Usually refers to oatmeal, a staple food in many cultures. Damage to meal could signify harm to fertility, growth, or sustenance.
Locations where community gatherings or important events took place, which could be affected or harmed through supernatural means.
A small river or stream. Damage to a burn could disrupt water supply or affect agriculture and livestock.
A house where cloth was dyed. Damage to a dye-house could affect textile production or livelihoods.
A ditch, wall, or mound used for drainage or as a boundary. Damage to a dyke could cause flooding or disrupt agricultural land.
A hill or mound traditionally believed to be a dwelling place of fairies. Damage to a fairy mound could result in supernatural retribution or misfortune.
A place where a river or stream can be crossed on foot or by vehicle. Damage to a ford could impact transportation and access to resources.
A valley between hills or mountains. Damage to a glen could disrupt agricultural activities or pose a threat to livestock.
A piece of level ground, usually alluvial, on the banks of a river. Damage to a haugh could affect farming or grazing land.
A small valley or depression in the landscape. Damage to a hollow could disrupt local ecology or pose a danger to travelers.
A hole, depression, or low-lying piece of ground. Damage to a howe could affect land stability or access to resources.
A stretch of undulating open, sandy ground. Damage to links could impact coastal habitats or disrupt local ecosystems.
A grassy track or pathway. Damage to a loan could affect transportation routes or access to agricultural land.
A lake or natural body of open water. Damage to a loch could impact fishing, transportation, or local water supply.
A marketplace where meal (oatmeal) was sold. Damage to a meal market could disrupt trade or food supply.
A place where seawater was evaporated to produce salt. Damage to a salt pan could impact local salt production and trade.
A prison or place to hold prisoners before trial. Damage to a ward could disrupt law enforcement or judicial proceedings.
Gatherings attended by witches, often described as engaging in rituals and activities associated with witchcraft and the occult.
The act of venerating or paying homage to the Devil, often involving rituals and ceremonies perceived as blasphemous by Christian standards.
Communal sexual activities or orgies reportedly conducted during witches' meetings, perceived as immoral and sinful by societal norms.
The use of harmful magic or sorcery conducted during witches' meetings, aimed at causing harm to individuals or communities.
The practice of causing harm to people, goods, or animals through magical means, often attributed to witches or sorcerers.
The ability of a witch or sorcerer to transform into different forms, often animals, as part of magical practice or to evade detection.
Various items used in magical or religious rituals, believed to possess symbolic or supernatural powers.
An alcoholic beverage, sometimes used in rituals for its symbolic or social significance, such as in reconciling disputes.
A non-native, exotic plant with associations to the Virgin Mary, used in rituals for its protective and spiritual qualities.
A protective charm, often a stone or pebble, worn or placed in a house to ward off evil or bring good fortune.
Latin for 'Water of Life,' referring to distilled spirits such as whisky, sometimes used in rituals or medicinal contexts.
The ash tree or its ashes, believed to have protective properties and used in religious and healing rituals.
A tool made of iron, used symbolically for protection against fairies or supernatural harm.
Cakes used in divination rituals or for luck and protection in some cultural practices.
A decorative item used as an amulet or offering in religious or magical rituals.
Associated with the Devil as 'coach horse,' used in rituals or as symbols of supernatural beings.
An item often associated with fertility or used in predicting outcomes of illnesses, sometimes used as a girdle in rituals.
Refers to a dead bird, sometimes used in rituals for transferring magical substances or causing harm.
Animal blood believed to carry special qualities that could be transferred to humans, used in rituals for healing or harm.
The last part of the body to decay, used symbolically in divination or rituals related to the soul or healing.
A Bible, religious missal, or herbal text believed to have magical properties in non-literate societies, used in divination or rituals.
A vessel with no specific symbolic use, used in rituals for transferring substances or as a receptacle in magical practices.
A part of a non-specified tree, some of which were believed to possess protective or magical powers.
An iron tool used to make marks on livestock for ownership or barrels for contents, sometimes used in punitive rituals.
An offering in supernatural rituals, believed to have protective or healing properties.
Similar to a belt, used in sympathetic magical rituals for protection or as a symbol.
Used in rituals for transferring substances or as part of magical practices, with no specific symbolic use.
A corpse or dead body used in rituals to transfer magical properties believed to reside in the deceased.
An instrument used in carding wool, possibly used in sympathetic magical rituals.
A medicinal herb known for its calming effects on digestion, used in rituals for protection or healing.
Used in rituals for transferring substances or as part of magical practices, with no specific symbolic use.
A healing charm, particularly black hens used to cure illnesses like epilepsy, associated with supernatural rituals.
Figures made of clay used in image magic to represent intended victims, a form of sympathetic magic.
Used to represent a sick person in rituals, blessed and returned as part of healing practices.
A symbolic weapon or phallus used in rituals for protection or as a staff of office.
Used as a good luck amulet in rituals or magical practices.
Left as a votive offering or used as an amulet in rituals or religious practices.
A vessel with no specific symbolic use, used in rituals for transferring substances or as a receptacle.
Powder made from the remains of a corpse, believed to possess magical properties of the deceased.
A tool used in spinning, with no specific symbolic use but possibly used in rituals or as a protective charm.
No specific symbolic use mentioned, but dogs historically had various associations and could be involved in rituals.
A Molluka bean from the West Indies, worn as a protective amulet or used in rituals to recover spoilt milk.
A liquid consumed for nourishment or refreshment, with no specific symbolic use mentioned.
As food, a supernatural symbol representing earth, life, and soul. Associated with fertility rites, Easter celebrations, and believed to have protective powers against fairies.
A prehistoric arrowhead believed to have been used by fairies or witches for causing harm. It could also serve as a protective amulet against such supernatural powers.
A feather with no specific symbolic use mentioned, often used in transference rituals or as a part of ceremonial attire.
Animal dung believed to possess healing properties, possibly used to transfer life force or for magical purposes.
A basic element associated with purifying powers and often used in symbolic and ritual events. In some contexts, fire may also have associations with hellfire.
A container typically carrying water, possibly used for holding holy water or other sacred substances in rituals.
Specifically animal meat (not human flesh), used in sympathetic magic for both harmful and healing purposes.
Leaves of the foxglove plant, a medicinal herb believed to affect the heart and used as an amulet against demonic powers.
Similar to a toad, associated with the Devil, sin, and impurity. Used in rituals for transference of disease or harm.
A non-specific garland made of plants or flowers, with no specific symbolic use mentioned.
A medicinal plant known for its antiseptic qualities and believed to drive away evil spirits. Used in various protective rituals.
A precious stone or jewel used as an amulet for its protective or healing properties in ritual practices.
A piece of glass or a non-specific glass object with no specific symbolic uses mentioned.
Similar in meaning to corn (grain), associated with fertility and growth in ritual contexts.
Grass with no specific symbolic use mentioned, but often associated with fertility and growth in cultural and ritual practices.
Earth taken from a grave, believed to possess magical properties associated with the dead.
Corn or grain waiting to be ground, with no specific symbolic uses mentioned but associated with fertility and growth.
Human or animal hair used in transference rituals or sympathetic magic, where it represents the person or animal it came from.
A belt made of hair with no specific symbolic use mentioned, used in rituals for transference or protective purposes.
The hand of a dead person believed to possess magical properties, used for providing protection or transferring such powers.
Non-specified medicinal herbs used in various ritual practices for their healing or protective properties.
A hook made of iron used for protection against the harmful powers of fairies or supernatural beings.
A protective symbol believed to ward off fairy powers due to its association with iron, used in various ritual practices.
Cats kept by farmers to control vermin, sometimes associated with magical powers or believed to be witches' familiars.
A woman's head covering or handkerchief, sometimes used in rituals or removed during curse or harmful rituals.
A sharp knife made of iron, used for protection against harmful fairy powers or in ritual practices.
A metal used for identifying illnesses or divining outcomes in certain ritual practices.
A small red stone encased in silver, believed to possess magical properties and used in healing rituals, according to the Lockhart of Lee family tradition.
Believed to be the seat of strength or courage, used in rituals to counteract harmful magic or provide protection.
A grain with no specific symbolic uses mentioned, associated with fertility and growth in ritual and cultural contexts.
Non-specified metal objects with traditional protective properties in various ritual practices.
Often offered as a libation or left as an offering to supernatural beings or spirits in ritual practices.
Feet of a mole, believed to possess magical properties linked to underground and demonic associations in ritual contexts.
Coins or money used as votive offerings or amulets for luck or protection in various ritual practices.
An iron nail used for protection against harmful fairy powers or in certain ritual practices.
Trimmed nails, which must be carefully disposed of to prevent illness transfer or use in witchcraft rituals. Used in sympathetic magic to represent the victim.
Also known as watercress, a medicinal plant with antiscorbutic qualities (preventing scurvy) and believed to increase appetite.
A medicinal plant effective against green venom, toothache, consumption (tuberculosis), and associated with protection against the Devil in folklore.
Used for anointing as part of healing rituals, symbolizing purification and blessing in various cultural and religious practices.
A non-specified salve or topical preparation applied for healing purposes, often associated with magical or medicinal properties.
A medicinal plant used in traditional medicine against sores, headaches, colds, fever, and warts, possibly with symbolic or protective uses.
Material on which prayers or gospel verses might be written, used as protective or healing amulets in ritual practices.
A pillow with no specific symbolic use mentioned in ritual contexts.
An iron pin used for protection against harmful fairy powers, often left as votive offerings at wells or shrines.
Non-specified medicinal plants used in various ritual practices for their healing or protective properties.
Also known as Wayburn leaf or waybread, common plantain, a sacred medicinal herb with diuretic and astringent properties used in healing rituals.
An iron plough used for protection against harmful fairy powers, possibly symbolizing fertility in agricultural and ritual contexts.
Non-specified salves or drinks with magical or medicinal properties used in ritual practices.
Oatmeal porridge with no specific ritual use mentioned.
Material with no specific symbolic uses mentioned, possibly referring to substances used in rituals, such as poisons or ground up materials.
A ribbon with no specific symbolic use mentioned but often used in rituals to tie around a sick person as part of healing practices.
Gold rings believed to have protective qualities against eye diseases in certain cultural and ritual practices.
A distaff used in spinning with no specific symbolic use mentioned in ritual contexts.
Also known as a cockerel, a sacred bird announcing the dawn, used in sacrificial rituals and divination practices.
Water with salt used for cleansing, purifying, and believed to have protective or healing qualities in ritual practices.
Spit associated with good luck or warding off evil, used in rituals to cure toothaches or warts.
Material possibly symbolizing the power of nature, fertility, and growth in ritual contexts.
Sharp iron shears used for protection against harmful fairy powers and sometimes used with a sieve for divination.
A crook made of iron used for protection against harmful fairy powers in ritual practices.
Used to represent the sick person in ritual practices, blessed and returned to them as part of a cure.
Associated with good or bad luck, often used in rituals related to marriage, fertility, or childbirth.
A tool used in divination rituals, often in conjunction with other objects like shears.
A highly prized metal associated with purity and used as protection against witchcraft or evil in ritual practices.
Smoke with no specific symbolic use mentioned, possibly associated with purifying powers of fire or used in fumigation rituals.
A snail with no specific symbolic use mentioned in ritual contexts.
Snakeskin with no specific symbolic use mentioned, possibly associated with the Devil in certain cultural or ritual contexts.
The upper layer of turf from harvesting, representing the power of nature, fertility, and growth in ritual practices.
Earth or soil believed to represent the power of nature, fertility, and growth in ritual and cultural practices.
Also known as Rowan, parts of the tree (leaves or branches) traditionally believed to protect against fairies and witches' harmful powers.
A spindle used in spinning with no specific symbolic use mentioned in ritual contexts.
A leather strap with no specific symbolic use mentioned, used in rituals for transference or binding purposes.
Straw with no specific symbolic use mentioned in ritual contexts.
A sword made of iron, used for protection against harmful fairy powers in ritual practices.
Salt used on tables or in rituals for cleansing, purifying, and believed to have protective or healing qualities.
Used in healing or harmful rituals, especially if stolen from an intended victim, to establish a connection or influence.
Cloth or textile used to represent a sick person, blessed and returned to them to provide healing or protection in ritual practices.
Often used to tie around a sick person as part of healing rituals, symbolizing connection, binding, or protection.
Similar to a frog, associated with the Devil, sin, and impurity in folklore. Used in rituals for transference of disease or negative energy.
A non-native, exotic plant with no specific symbolic use mentioned, but regarded as medicinal in various cultural contexts.
Non-specified trees associated with healing or protective powers in ritual practices across different cultures.
Urine with no specific symbolic uses mentioned but often used in healing rituals or medicines in certain cultural practices.
Vinegar with no specific symbolic use mentioned, used as an ingredient in various cultural practices.
Life-giving and associated with the healing power of nature, spirits, and saints in various ritual and religious contexts.
Figures or pictures made of wax used in image magic to represent the intended victim in sympathetic magic, often used for healing or harming rituals.
An image made of wax used in image magic to represent the intended victim in sympathetic magic, often used in rituals for healing or harming purposes.
Wheat with no specific symbolic uses mentioned, but as living grain associated with fertility and growth in various cultural and ritual practices.
Wine with no specific symbolic use mentioned, but considered an unusual ingredient in certain ritual practices, possibly with religious symbolism.
Non-specified type of wood with potential special properties in various ritual practices across cultures.
An infusion of malt fermented to make ale, with no specific symbolic use mentioned but used in cultural and ritual contexts.
Woollen thread or yarn often used to tie around a sick person as part of healing rituals, symbolizing connection, binding, or protection.
